funFact.level8: Ashkenazi founder mutations show strong linkage disequilibrium with flanking markers, dating their origins to ~30-40 generations ago during population bottlenecks.

inheritanceExplanation.level3: If one parent has a BRCA mutation, children have a 50% chance of inheriting it.
inheritanceExplanation.level4: BRCA mutations are dominant for cancer risk - one mutated copy significantly increases cancer risk.
inheritanceExplanation.level5: BRCA cancer risk follows autosomal dominant inheritance. A single inherited mutation dramatically increases lifetime cancer risk.
inheritanceExplanation.level6: BRCA-associated cancer predisposition shows autosomal dominant inheritance with high but incomplete penetrance, modified by other genetic and environmental factors.
inheritanceExplanation.level7: BRCA cancer susceptibility is inherited as autosomal dominant with age-dependent penetrance of 40-85% for breast and 15-45% for ovarian cancer.
inheritanceExplanation.level8: BRCA cancer predisposition follows autosomal dominant inheritance at the phenotypic level, with tumor development requiring somatic second-hit LOH following Knudson's two-hit model.

traits.prevalence: ~1 in 400 in general population; ~1 in 40 in Ashkenazi Jewish population

traits.name: APOE and Alzheimer's Risk

shortDescription.level3: A gene that affects brain health as you get older!
shortDescription.level4: The APOE gene affects cholesterol in the brain and Alzheimer's disease risk.
shortDescription.level5: APOE has three versions (ε2, ε3, ε4) with different effects on Alzheimer's risk.
shortDescription.level6: APOE ε4 is the strongest common genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer's disease.
shortDescription.level7: APOE ε4 increases Alzheimer's risk ~3-fold per allele through effects on amyloid-β clearance and aggregation.
shortDescription.level8: APOE isoforms differentially affect Aβ clearance, aggregation kinetics, and tau pathology; ε4 impairs microglial Aβ phagocytosis and promotes neuroinflammation.

longDescription.level3: APOE is a gene that helps move fats around in your body and brain. One version of this gene makes it more likely to develop Alzheimer's disease when you're older.
longDescription.level4: The APOE gene has three versions: ε2, ε3, and ε4. The ε4 version increases the chance of developing Alzheimer's disease, while ε2 may be protective. Most people have ε3.
longDescription.level5: APOE encodes a protein that transports cholesterol, including in the brain. The ε4 variant is associated with earlier onset and higher risk of Alzheimer's disease, affecting how the brain clears toxic proteins.
longDescription.level6: APOE ε4 is the strongest common genetic risk factor for Alzheimer's. One copy increases risk ~3-fold; two copies increase risk ~12-fold. The ε2 allele appears protective.
longDescription.level7: APOE ε4 impairs amyloid-β clearance and promotes its aggregation into plaques. The variant also affects tau pathology, synaptic function, and neuroinflammatory responses.
longDescription.level8: APOE4 reduces microglial Aβ phagocytosis, accelerates Aβ fibril formation, and promotes neuroinflammatory TREM2 signaling. Effects on tau pathology and synaptic integrity are partially Aβ-independent.

funFact.level3: Having the risky gene version doesn't mean you'll definitely get Alzheimer's!
funFact.level4: Many people with APOE ε4 never develop Alzheimer's, and many people without it do. It's just one risk factor among many.
funFact.level5: APOE ε4 may have been beneficial to our ancestors - some evidence suggests it helped with survival in environments with high infectious disease burden.
funFact.level6: The ε4 allele may have been ancestral and beneficial for immune function, with ε3 and ε2 arising as derived alleles as human lifespan extended.
funFact.level7: APOE ε4 is ancestral in primates and may have conferred immune advantages; the Alzheimer's association only becomes relevant with modern extended lifespans.
funFact.level8: The ε4 allele shows geographic variation potentially related to ancestral infectious disease exposure, with higher frequencies in some African and Oceanian populations.

variants.effect: C allele = part of ε4 haplotype (increased Alzheimer's risk)
T allele = part of ε2 haplotype (decreased Alzheimer's risk)

inheritanceExplanation.level3: Your Alzheimer's risk depends on which APOE versions you got from your parents!
inheritanceExplanation.level4: Having two copies of ε4 gives higher risk than one copy. Having ε2 may lower your risk.
inheritanceExplanation.level5: APOE shows additive effects on Alzheimer's risk: each ε4 copy increases risk, while ε2 appears protective.
inheritanceExplanation.level6: APOE genotype effects on Alzheimer's are roughly multiplicative: ε4/ε4 ~12x risk, ε3/ε4 ~3x, ε2/ε3 ~0.6x compared to ε3/ε3.
inheritanceExplanation.level7: APOE shows dose-dependent effects on Alzheimer's risk with age-dependent penetrance; ε4/ε4 homozygotes have ~50% risk by age 75.
inheritanceExplanation.level8: APOE genotype modifies Alzheimer's risk in a roughly log-additive manner, with effects modified by sex, ancestry, and other genetic variants.

traits.prevalence: ε4 allele: ~14% globally; ε4/ε4: ~2% of population

traits.name: Huntington's Disease

shortDescription.level3: A brain disease caused by a gene with too many repeats!
shortDescription.level4: Huntington's is caused by a repeated DNA sequence that's too long.
shortDescription.level5: HTT gene CAG repeat expansion causes a neurodegenerative disease affecting movement and cognition.
shortDescription.level6: Huntington's disease results from CAG trinucleotide repeat expansion in HTT, causing toxic polyglutamine protein.
shortDescription.level7: HTT CAG repeat expansion (>35 repeats) causes dominant neurodegeneration with age of onset inversely correlated with repeat length.
shortDescription.level8: HTT exon 1 CAG expansion produces polyglutamine-expanded huntingtin, forming toxic aggregates and disrupting transcription, proteostasis, and mitochondrial function.

longDescription.level3: The HTT gene has a part that repeats itself. If it repeats too many times (more than 35), it causes Huntington's disease, which affects movement and thinking.
longDescription.level4: In the HTT gene, three DNA letters (CAG) repeat over and over. Normal genes have 10-35 repeats. More than 35 repeats cause Huntington's disease, which usually appears in adulthood.
longDescription.level5: Huntington's disease is caused by an expansion of CAG repeats in the HTT gene. These repeats code for the amino acid glutamine. An expanded string of glutamines makes the huntingtin protein toxic to brain cells.
longDescription.level6: HTT CAG repeat expansion creates a polyglutamine tract that causes protein misfolding and aggregation. Longer expansions cause earlier onset; >60 repeats typically cause juvenile-onset disease.
longDescription.level7: The HTT polyglutamine tract normally has 10-26 glutamines. Expansions of 36+ cause disease, with age of onset inversely correlated with repeat length following an exponential relationship.
longDescription.level8: Expanded polyglutamine in huntingtin disrupts interactions with multiple partners, impairs autophagy and proteasomal degradation, causes transcriptional dysregulation, and triggers mitochondrial dysfunction and excitotoxicity.

funFact.level3: This was one of the first genetic diseases where scientists found the exact gene!
funFact.level4: Scientists spent 10 years searching for the Huntington's gene, finally finding it in 1993 in a collaborative effort.
funFact.level5: Huntington's disease was mapped using families from Venezuela where the disease is unusually common due to a founder effect.
funFact.level6: The Lake Maracaibo kindred in Venezuela, with ~18,000 related individuals including many HD cases, was crucial for mapping the HTT gene.
funFact.level7: The Lake Maracaibo HD cluster traces to a single 19th-century woman; this large pedigree enabled linkage mapping before the CAG repeat was identified.
funFact.level8: HD gene mapping leveraged RFLPs in the Lake Maracaibo kindred, with fine mapping revealing the CAG repeat expansion in 1993 by the HD Collaborative Research Group.

inheritanceExplanation.level3: If one parent has Huntington's, children have a 50% chance of getting it.
inheritanceExplanation.level4: Huntington's is dominant - you only need one copy of the expanded gene to develop the disease.
inheritanceExplanation.level5: Huntington's disease follows autosomal dominant inheritance with complete penetrance for expansions of 40+ repeats.
inheritanceExplanation.level6: HD shows autosomal dominant inheritance with age-dependent but complete penetrance. Repeat lengths of 36-39 show reduced penetrance.
inheritanceExplanation.level7: HTT CAG expansions show autosomal dominant inheritance with anticipation - repeats can expand during transmission, especially through paternal inheritance.
inheritanceExplanation.level8: HD exhibits meiotic instability with somatic mosaicism and anticipation; paternal transmission shows greater expansion due to CAG instability during spermatogenesis.

traits.prevalence: ~1 in 10,000 in European ancestry populations; rarer in Asian and African populations

traits.name: Sprinter vs Endurance Gene

shortDescription.level3: Whether you're built for sprinting or long-distance running!
shortDescription.level4: A gene that affects if your muscles are better for speed or endurance.
shortDescription.level5: ACTN3 determines your ratio of fast-twitch to slow-twitch muscle fibers.
shortDescription.level6: ACTN3 encodes α-actinin-3 in fast-twitch muscle fibers; a common null variant affects athletic performance.
shortDescription.level7: The ACTN3 R577X polymorphism eliminates α-actinin-3 from fast fibers, shifting muscle toward endurance phenotype.
shortDescription.level8: ACTN3 577XX homozygotes lack α-actinin-3, causing metabolic shift toward oxidative metabolism and improved endurance at the cost of sprint power.

longDescription.level3: Your muscles can be built for quick bursts of speed or for running a long time. A gene called ACTN3 helps decide which type you have more of!
longDescription.level4: ACTN3 makes a protein found in fast-twitch muscle fibers - the kind used for sprinting. Some people have a version that doesn't work, so their muscles are better at endurance activities instead.
longDescription.level5: The ACTN3 gene makes α-actinin-3, a protein in fast-twitch muscles. About 18% of people have two copies of a variant that stops this protein from working. These people tend to be better at endurance sports than sprinting.
longDescription.level6: ACTN3 R577X creates a premature stop codon. The XX genotype is virtually absent in elite sprinters but common in endurance athletes. The α-actinin-3 protein is specific to fast type II fibers.
longDescription.level7: ACTN3 577XX causes complete α-actinin-3 deficiency, shifting muscle metabolism toward oxidative pathways. This genotype is found in <1% of Olympic sprinters but ~25% of elite endurance athletes.
longDescription.level8: α-actinin-3 deficiency causes slow fiber metabolic adaptation via calcineurin signaling, increased glycogen storage, and enhanced fatigue resistance at the expense of power output.

funFact.level3: No Olympic 100m finalist has ever had two copies of the 'endurance' version!
funFact.level4: Almost every Olympic sprinter has at least one working copy of ACTN3, while many marathon runners don't.
funFact.level5: The 'endurance' version of ACTN3 became common as humans migrated to colder climates where endurance was more important than speed.
funFact.level6: ACTN3 577X shows evidence of positive selection in European and East Asian populations, possibly for metabolic efficiency in cold climates.
funFact.level7: The ACTN3 577X allele increased from ~10% to ~50% in Europeans over the last 30,000 years, suggesting selection for endurance/thermoregulation.
funFact.level8: ACTN3 577X shows latitudinal gradient suggesting selection for improved thermogenesis and endurance metabolism in cold environments.

variants.effect: C/C = power/sprint; T/T = endurance; C/T = intermediate

inheritanceExplanation.level3: You get muscle-type genes from both parents!
inheritanceExplanation.level4: Having one sprint gene and one endurance gene gives you a mix of both muscle types.
inheritanceExplanation.level5: ACTN3 shows codominant effects - heterozygotes have intermediate muscle fiber characteristics.
inheritanceExplanation.level6: The R577X polymorphism shows additive effects on muscle phenotype, with heterozygotes intermediate in fiber composition.
inheritanceExplanation.level7: ACTN3 exhibits codominant inheritance with genotype-dependent α-actinin-3 protein levels and proportional phenotypic effects.
inheritanceExplanation.level8: ACTN3 shows additive effects on fast fiber percentage, power output, and muscle metabolism with heterozygotes intermediate.

traits.prevalence: RR (sprint): ~30%, RX (mixed): ~50%, XX (endurance): ~18-20% in Europeans

traits.name: Caffeine Metabolism Speed

shortDescription.level3: How fast your body breaks down coffee!
shortDescription.level4: Some people process caffeine quickly, others slowly.
shortDescription.level5: CYP1A2 determines how fast you metabolize caffeine from coffee and tea.
shortDescription.level6: CYP1A2 variants affect caffeine half-life, influencing tolerance and health effects.
shortDescription.level7: CYP1A2 -163C>A polymorphism affects enzyme inducibility, with AA genotype showing faster caffeine clearance.
shortDescription.level8: CYP1A2*1F (rs762551 A>C) affects AhR-mediated enzyme induction, with C allele reducing inducibility and slowing caffeine metabolism.

longDescription.level3: When you drink coffee, your body has to break down the caffeine. Some people do this fast and can drink coffee at night, while others do it slowly and feel jittery all day!
longDescription.level4: The CYP1A2 gene makes an enzyme that breaks down caffeine. Fast metabolizers can drink coffee late without trouble, while slow metabolizers may feel wired for hours from one cup.
longDescription.level5: CYP1A2 is responsible for ~95% of caffeine metabolism. Fast metabolizers (AA genotype) clear caffeine quickly and may need more coffee for effects. Slow metabolizers (C carriers) feel effects longer and may have health risks from high intake.
longDescription.level6: The CYP1A2 -163A>C variant affects enzyme induction. Slow metabolizers who drink 3+ cups daily have increased heart attack risk, while fast metabolizers show no increased risk or even protective effects.
longDescription.level7: CYP1A2*1F shows gene-diet interaction: slow metabolizers have increased MI risk with high caffeine intake, while fast metabolizers may benefit from caffeine's antioxidant effects.
longDescription.level8: CYP1A2 inducibility affects caffeine pharmacokinetics with half-life ranging from 2-12 hours. Slow metabolizers show impaired exercise ergogenic response and elevated cardiovascular risk markers.

funFact.level3: About half of people are slow caffeine metabolizers!
funFact.level4: Slow metabolizers who drink lots of coffee have higher heart attack risk, but fast metabolizers don't!
funFact.level5: Whether coffee is 'good' or 'bad' for your heart partly depends on how fast you metabolize it - the research was confusing until scientists accounted for this gene.
funFact.level6: The conflicting research on coffee and heart disease was partly resolved by finding that CYP1A2 genotype moderates the association.
funFact.level7: CYP1A2 genotype explains ~15% of the variance in caffeine clearance rates between individuals.
funFact.level8: Caffeine pharmacokinetics show 40-fold inter-individual variation, with CYP1A2 genotype, smoking status, and oral contraceptive use as major determinants.

variants.effect: A/A = fast metabolizer; A/C or C/C = slow metabolizer

inheritanceExplanation.level3: You inherit caffeine speed from both parents!
inheritanceExplanation.level4: Having one fast and one slow gene gives you medium caffeine metabolism.
inheritanceExplanation.level5: CYP1A2 metabolism speed is additive - two fast copies means fastest metabolism.
inheritanceExplanation.level6: CYP1A2 activity shows additive inheritance with heterozygotes having intermediate metabolism rates.
inheritanceExplanation.level7: CYP1A2 phenotype is polygenic but the -163C>A polymorphism explains a substantial proportion of inter-individual variation.
inheritanceExplanation.level8: CYP1A2 activity is determined by genetic polymorphisms plus environmental inducers (smoking, cruciferous vegetables) in a multiplicative model.

traits.prevalence: Fast metabolizers (AA): ~45%, Slow metabolizers (AC/CC): ~55%

traits.name: Natural Short Sleeper

shortDescription.level3: Some people only need 4-6 hours of sleep!
shortDescription.level4: Rare gene variants let some people thrive on less sleep.
shortDescription.level5: DEC2/BHLHE41 mutations cause 'natural short sleep' - needing only 4-6 hours.
shortDescription.level6: Rare BHLHE41 variants reduce sleep need without cognitive deficits seen in sleep deprivation.
shortDescription.level7: BHLHE41 P384R and other mutations affect circadian regulation, reducing total sleep need to 4-6 hours.
shortDescription.level8: BHLHE41 mutations impair repressor activity on CLOCK/BMAL1 targets, altering circadian gene expression and reducing homeostatic sleep drive.

longDescription.level3: Most people need 7-9 hours of sleep, but some lucky people have a special gene that lets them feel great with only 4-6 hours!
longDescription.level4: Natural short sleepers have a rare mutation that makes their bodies need less sleep. They wake up refreshed after only 4-6 hours and don't feel tired during the day - unlike people who just don't get enough sleep.
longDescription.level5: The DEC2 gene (also called BHLHE41) helps control your body's internal clock. Rare mutations in this gene reduce the need for sleep without the negative effects of sleep deprivation. These people are truly refreshed on less sleep.
longDescription.level6: BHLHE41 encodes a transcriptional repressor in the circadian clock. The P384R mutation was discovered in a family that habitually slept only 6 hours without impairment. Mice with this mutation also sleep less.
longDescription.level7: Natural short sleep mutations in BHLHE41, ADRB1, and NPSR1 have been identified. These affect circadian/sleep homeostasis pathways and confer resistance to sleep deprivation effects.
longDescription.level8: BHLHE41 P384R reduces transcriptional repression of circadian targets including PER genes. ADRB1 A187V affects noradrenergic signaling in the pons, reducing NREM sleep.

funFact.level3: Famous short sleepers include Elon Musk and Margaret Thatcher!
funFact.level4: True natural short sleepers are very rare - only about 1-3% of people who claim to need little sleep actually have the gene.
funFact.level5: Scientists found this gene by studying a mother and daughter who both slept only 6 hours and woke naturally with no alarm clock.
funFact.level6: Most people who think they're short sleepers actually have accumulated sleep debt. True genetic short sleepers show no cognitive decline on 4-6 hours.
funFact.level7: The familial natural short sleep phenotype was first mapped in 2009. Multiple genes have now been implicated (BHLHE41, ADRB1, NPSR1, GRM1).
funFact.level8: Identified short sleep mutations affect distinct pathways: circadian (BHLHE41), arousal (ADRB1, NPSR1), and neuronal excitability (GRM1), suggesting multiple routes to reduced sleep need.

inheritanceExplanation.level3: If one parent is a natural short sleeper, children might be too!
inheritanceExplanation.level4: Short sleep mutations are dominant - you only need one copy to need less sleep.
inheritanceExplanation.level5: Natural short sleep follows dominant inheritance - affected families show the trait across generations.
inheritanceExplanation.level6: Familial natural short sleep is autosomal dominant with high penetrance in identified pedigrees.
inheritanceExplanation.level7: Short sleep mutations show dominant inheritance with full penetrance; identified mutations are private to individual families.
inheritanceExplanation.level8: Identified short sleep mutations are rare, often private variants showing autosomal dominant inheritance with complete penetrance.

traits.prevalence: Extremely rare (<0.5% of population); most 'short sleepers' are sleep deprived

traits.name: Morning Lark vs Night Owl

shortDescription.level3: Whether you're naturally an early bird or a night person!
shortDescription.level4: Your genes help determine if you're a morning person or a night owl.
shortDescription.level5: Clock genes like PER2 and CLOCK influence your natural sleep-wake preferences.
shortDescription.level6: Chronotype is influenced by circadian gene variants affecting your endogenous rhythm period.
shortDescription.level7: PER2, PER3, CLOCK, and CRY variants affect circadian period length and phase preference.
shortDescription.level8: Chronotype is polygenic with GWAS identifying 351 loci; PER2/3 variants alter phosphorylation-dependent protein stability affecting period length.

longDescription.level3: Are you bright and happy in the morning, or do you come alive at night? It's partly in your genes!
longDescription.level4: Your body has an internal clock that tells you when to sleep and wake. Some people's clocks run a bit fast (morning larks), while others run slow (night owls).
longDescription.level5: Genes like PER2, PER3, and CLOCK control your circadian rhythm - your body's 24-hour cycle. Variants in these genes can make your natural schedule earlier or later than average.
longDescription.level6: Chronotype is ~50% heritable. Key clock genes form transcription-translation feedback loops with ~24-hour periodicity. Genetic variants can shorten (morningness) or lengthen (eveningness) this period.
longDescription.level7: The PER3 VNTR (4/4 vs 5/5 repeats) is associated with morningness and sleep homeostasis. Extreme morning types may carry PER2 or CRY mutations causing Familial Advanced Sleep Phase.
longDescription.level8: Circadian period is determined by the phosphorylation-dependent degradation rate of PER proteins. CK1ε mutations in FASPS accelerate PER2 degradation, shortening period by ~4 hours.

funFact.level3: Teenagers naturally become night owls - it's biology, not laziness!
funFact.level4: Circadian rhythms shift later during puberty, which is why teens want to sleep late. It shifts back as adults.
funFact.level5: Studies forcing teenagers to start school later show improved grades, fewer car accidents, and better mental health.
funFact.level6: Adolescent circadian phase delay is driven by hormonal changes affecting clock gene expression, not just social factors.
funFact.level7: Pubertal hormones modulate circadian photosensitivity and period length, causing ~2-hour phase delay in adolescents.
funFact.level8: Adolescent chronotype shift involves altered melatonin sensitivity, changed PER2 expression patterns, and modified light input to the SCN.

variants.effect: Associated with morningness

inheritanceExplanation.level3: Being a morning or night person comes from many genes!
inheritanceExplanation.level4: Your chronotype is influenced by many genes working together.
inheritanceExplanation.level5: Chronotype is about 50% genetic, involving hundreds of genes that affect your internal clock.
inheritanceExplanation.level6: GWAS have identified 351 loci associated with chronotype, explaining ~12% of variance.
inheritanceExplanation.level7: Chronotype is highly polygenic with many small-effect variants; heritability estimates range from 21-52%.
inheritanceExplanation.level8: Chronotype GWAS signal is enriched in brain-expressed genes and retinal phototransduction pathways, reflecting central clock and light input roles.

traits.prevalence: Morning types: ~25%, Evening types: ~25%, Intermediate: ~50%

traits.name: Photic Sneeze Reflex

shortDescription.level3: Sneezing when you look at bright light!
shortDescription.level4: Some people sneeze when they walk from dark to bright light.
shortDescription.level5: The photic sneeze reflex (ACHOO syndrome) makes people sneeze when exposed to bright light.
shortDescription.level6: Photic sneezing is an autosomal dominant trait affecting 18-35% of the population.
shortDescription.level7: ACHOO syndrome involves cross-activation between optic and trigeminal nerve pathways.
shortDescription.level8: Photic sneeze reflex results from parasympathetic cross-wiring between visual and sneeze reflex pathways, possibly in the lateral medulla.

longDescription.level3: Do you sneeze when you walk outside into bright sunlight? About 1 in 4 people do! Scientists call it ACHOO syndrome.
longDescription.level4: The photic sneeze reflex makes people sneeze when suddenly exposed to bright light. It's completely harmless and runs in families.
longDescription.level5: ACHOO stands for 'Autosomal dominant Compelling Helio-Ophthalmic Outburst.' About 18-35% of people have it. The bright light triggers the same nerves that make you sneeze.
longDescription.level6: Photic sneezing results from parasympathetic generalization - bright light stimulates pupil constriction and the nearby sneeze reflex gets cross-activated.
longDescription.level7: The reflex involves the optic nerve (vision) cross-activating the trigeminal nerve (sneeze reflex) at the level of the brainstem, likely due to nerve proximity.
longDescription.level8: Proposed mechanisms include ephaptic transmission between optic and trigeminal pathways, or central parasympathetic overflow at the superior salivatory nucleus.

funFact.level3: Aristotle wrote about sun-sneezing over 2,000 years ago!
funFact.level4: The funny ACHOO acronym was invented by scientists in the 1970s as a joke that stuck.
funFact.level5: Fighter pilots with photic sneeze reflex can be dangerous during combat, so militaries screen for it.
funFact.level6: Photic sneeze is a concern in aviation and military contexts where sudden sneezing during bright light exposure could be hazardous.
funFact.level7: The genetic basis remains unmapped despite the clear dominant inheritance pattern, suggesting complex or heterogeneous etiology.
funFact.level8: Despite ~40% heritability and clear Mendelian segregation, no specific locus for photic sneeze reflex has been identified in GWAS.

inheritanceExplanation.level3: If your mom or dad sneezes at light, you probably do too!
inheritanceExplanation.level4: Sun-sneezing is dominant - you only need one copy of the gene to have it.
inheritanceExplanation.level5: Photic sneeze follows autosomal dominant inheritance with high penetrance.
inheritanceExplanation.level6: Family studies confirm autosomal dominant inheritance with ~67% penetrance in first-degree relatives.
inheritanceExplanation.level7: Photic sneeze shows autosomal dominant inheritance but no causative gene has been identified.
inheritanceExplanation.level8: The phenotype segregates as autosomal dominant in pedigrees, but genetic heterogeneity or reduced penetrance has hampered gene identification.

traits.prevalence: 18-35% of population

traits.name: Asparagus Urine Smell

shortDescription.level3: Whether you can smell the funny smell after eating asparagus!
shortDescription.level4: Some people can smell asparagus metabolites in urine, while others can't.
shortDescription.level5: The ability to smell asparagus metabolites in urine is genetic, involving olfactory receptor genes.
shortDescription.level6: OR2M7 gene variants determine ability to detect asparagus-derived methanethiol and related compounds.
shortDescription.level7: A cluster of olfactory receptor genes near OR2M7 determines asparagus anosmia, affecting ~40% of people.
shortDescription.level8: GWAS identified rs4481887 near OR2M7 as strongly associated with asparagus anosmia, affecting odor threshold for methanethiol.

longDescription.level3: After eating asparagus, some people notice a strong smell when they pee. But other people can't smell it at all - even though everyone makes the smelly chemical!
longDescription.level4: Almost everyone produces smelly chemicals in their urine after eating asparagus. But about 40% of people have olfactory receptor variants that make them unable to detect the smell.
longDescription.level5: Asparagus contains compounds that break down into sulfur-containing chemicals like methanethiol. Whether you can smell them depends on variants in olfactory receptor genes near OR2M7.
longDescription.level6: The asparagus urine smell comes from S-methyl thioesters produced during metabolism. Detection ability is determined by olfactory receptor variants on chromosome 1, with ~40% of people having specific anosmia.
longDescription.level7: GWAS identified variants near OR2M7 explaining asparagus-specific anosmia. Interestingly, early studies focused on who produces the smell, but production is nearly universal - detection is the variable.
longDescription.level8: The rs4481887 variant near OR2M7 on chromosome 1 shows OR = 2.4 for asparagus anosmia. The olfactory receptor cluster shows signatures of balancing selection in human populations.

funFact.level3: Everyone makes the smelly pee - but only some people can smell it!
funFact.level4: Scientists used to think only some people made the smell. Now we know almost everyone makes it, but only some can detect it!
funFact.level5: Benjamin Franklin wrote about asparagus pee in 1781, noting it gives urine 'a disagreeable odour.'
funFact.level6: Marcel Proust famously wrote that asparagus 'transforms my chamber-pot into a flask of perfume.'
funFact.level7: The metabolites responsible include methanethiol, dimethyl sulfide, and dimethyl sulfoxide, produced within 15-30 minutes of ingestion.
funFact.level8: Asparagusic acid is the precursor, converted to volatile sulfur compounds. Detection threshold for methanethiol varies 1000-fold between individuals based on genotype.

variants.effect: A allele = more likely to smell asparagus urine

inheritanceExplanation.level3: Smelling asparagus pee runs in families in complicated ways!
inheritanceExplanation.level4: Multiple genes affect whether you can smell asparagus urine.
inheritanceExplanation.level5: The ability to smell asparagus metabolites involves multiple olfactory receptor genes.
inheritanceExplanation.level6: Asparagus anosmia shows complex inheritance with multiple contributing OR gene variants.
inheritanceExplanation.level7: GWAS identifies a major locus near OR2M7 but additional variants likely contribute to the phenotype.
inheritanceExplanation.level8: Asparagus detection shows complex genetics with OR2M7 region explaining ~17% of variance in detection ability.

traits.prevalence: Can smell: ~60%, Cannot smell (anosmia): ~40%

traits.name: Body Odor Intensity

shortDescription.level3: Some people have almost no body odor!
shortDescription.level4: The same gene that controls earwax type also affects body odor.
shortDescription.level5: ABCC11 variants that cause dry earwax also greatly reduce body odor.
shortDescription.level6: ABCC11 538G>A eliminates apocrine gland odor precursor secretion, reducing body odor.
shortDescription.level7: ABCC11 538A/A genotype produces minimal body odor due to absent apocrine odor precursor secretion.
shortDescription.level8: ABCC11 transports odor precursors (16-androstene steroids, short-chain fatty acids) into apocrine sweat; 538A eliminates transport function.

longDescription.level3: The same gene that decides if your earwax is wet or dry also controls body odor. People with dry earwax have almost no body odor!
longDescription.level4: ABCC11 is the earwax gene, but it also affects your sweat glands. People with two copies of the dry earwax variant produce much less body odor.
longDescription.level5: The ABCC11 gene controls what gets secreted by apocrine sweat glands (found in armpits). The variant that causes dry earwax also stops the secretion of chemicals that bacteria turn into body odor.
longDescription.level6: ABCC11 transports odor precursors into apocrine sweat. The 538A variant eliminates this transport, so bacteria have nothing to convert to odorous compounds. This is why most East Asians don't need deodorant.
longDescription.level7: ABCC11 538A/A individuals secrete minimal 3M2H and other odor precursors. Axillary microbiome composition also differs, with reduced Corynebacterium colonization.
longDescription.level8: ABCC11 exports glutathione conjugates of odorant precursors. 538A causes ER retention and proteasomal degradation, eliminating secretion of 3-methyl-2-hexenoic acid and androstenone/androstenol precursors.

funFact.level3: Deodorant was invented in America and Europe - most people in East Asia don't need it!
funFact.level4: About 80-95% of East Asians have the variant for dry earwax and low body odor, compared to only ~2% of Europeans.
funFact.level5: In Japan and Korea, having body odor was historically so unusual that it was classified as a medical condition (osmidrosis) that could exempt men from military service.
funFact.level6: The global deodorant market reflects genetics: East Asian markets are much smaller per capita because most people don't need these products.
funFact.level7: The ABCC11 538A allele was positively selected in East Asia ~2000 generations ago, possibly due to pleiotropic effects or sexual selection.
funFact.level8: Population genetics suggest ABCC11 538A swept to near-fixation in East Asia during the last glacial maximum, possibly due to effects on thermoregulation or pathogen resistance.

variants.effect: G/G or G/A = normal body odor; A/A = minimal body odor

inheritanceExplanation.level3: You need two copies of the gene to have almost no body odor!
inheritanceExplanation.level4: Minimal body odor is recessive - you need two copies of the variant.
inheritanceExplanation.level5: Like dry earwax, minimal body odor requires two copies (A/A) of the variant.
inheritanceExplanation.level6: Body odor reduction follows recessive inheritance; heterozygotes have intermediate but still functional ABCC11.
inheritanceExplanation.level7: The body odor phenotype parallels earwax: A/A = minimal odor, G/A = intermediate, G/G = normal.
inheritanceExplanation.level8: Heterozygotes produce ~50% functional ABCC11, secreting intermediate levels of odor precursors.

traits.prevalence: Minimal body odor (A/A): ~2% Europeans, ~80-95% East Asians

traits.name: Red-Green Color Blindness

shortDescription.level3: When reds and greens look similar!
shortDescription.level4: Color blindness makes it hard to tell red and green apart.
shortDescription.level5: Red-green color blindness is caused by mutations in cone pigment genes on the X chromosome.
shortDescription.level6: OPN1LW and OPN1MW encode red and green cone opsins; deletions or mutations cause color vision deficiency.
shortDescription.level7: Red-green CVD results from unequal crossing-over in the OPN1LW-OPN1MW gene array, causing deletion or hybrid genes.
shortDescription.level8: The OPN1LW/MW tandem array is prone to unequal recombination due to high sequence similarity, causing deuteranopia/protanopia.

longDescription.level3: Color blindness usually means having trouble telling red and green apart. It's much more common in boys because it's carried on the X chromosome.
longDescription.level4: Your eyes have three types of cone cells for color: red, green, and blue. Color blindness happens when the red or green cones don't work properly. Boys are affected more because they only have one X chromosome.
longDescription.level5: The genes for red and green light detection (OPN1LW and OPN1MW) are on the X chromosome. Because males have only one X, a single mutation causes color blindness. Females need mutations on both X chromosomes.
longDescription.level6: Red-green CVD affects ~8% of males but only ~0.5% of females due to X-linkage. The OPN1LW-OPN1MW gene cluster undergoes frequent unequal recombination, creating deletions or hybrid genes.
longDescription.level7: Deuteranomaly (weak green) and protanomaly (weak red) result from hybrid pigment genes; deuteranopia and protanopia result from gene deletions. Gene conversion between OPN1LW/MW causes spectral shifts.
longDescription.level8: The high mutation rate results from the tandem array structure with 98% sequence identity promoting unequal crossing over. Each male conception has ~4% de novo CVD mutation risk.

funFact.level3: About 1 in 12 boys is color blind, but only 1 in 200 girls!
funFact.level4: Color blind people often have enhanced night vision and can sometimes spot camouflaged objects better than normal vision people.
funFact.level5: During WWII, color blind soldiers were valued as spotters because they could see through some types of camouflage.
funFact.level6: Daltonism is named after John Dalton, who described his own color blindness in 1794 - his preserved eyeball was later genetically tested.
funFact.level7: Analysis of John Dalton's preserved eyes in 1995 showed he had deuteranopia (missing green pigment), not the protanopia he had hypothesized.
funFact.level8: Gene therapy trials (CRISPR-based opsin delivery to cones) have shown partial color vision restoration in primate models.

inheritanceExplanation.level3: Boys are color blind more often because they only have one X chromosome!
inheritanceExplanation.level4: Color blindness is X-linked recessive. Boys have one X, so one mutation causes color blindness. Girls have two X chromosomes and usually have a backup.
inheritanceExplanation.level5: Red-green color blindness is X-linked recessive. Males (XY) express the phenotype with one mutation, while females (XX) are usually carriers.
inheritanceExplanation.level6: X-linked recessive inheritance means affected males inherit the mutation from carrier mothers. Affected females are rare and require affected father + carrier mother.
inheritanceExplanation.level7: Manifesting heterozygotes (color blind females) can occur due to skewed X-inactivation, but full CVD requires homozygosity.
inheritanceExplanation.level8: Carrier females may show subtle CVD on anomaloscopy due to X-inactivation mosaicism in retinal cone populations.

traits.prevalence: Males: ~8%, Females: ~0.5%

traits.name: Congenital Pain Insensitivity

shortDescription.level3: Some rare people feel no pain at all!
shortDescription.level4: Extremely rare mutations can make people unable to feel pain.
shortDescription.level5: SCN9A gene mutations can cause complete inability to feel pain.
shortDescription.level6: SCN9A encodes Nav1.7, a sodium channel in pain neurons; loss-of-function causes pain insensitivity.
shortDescription.level7: SCN9A loss-of-function mutations prevent action potential initiation in nociceptors, causing congenital insensitivity to pain.
shortDescription.level8: Nav1.7 is required for odor perception and nociceptor function; null mutations cause CIP with anosmia while preserving mechanosensation.

longDescription.level3: A very small number of people are born unable to feel any pain. While that might sound like a superpower, it's actually dangerous because pain warns us of injury.
longDescription.level4: The SCN9A gene makes a protein needed for pain signals to reach your brain. Rare mutations that break this gene make people completely unable to feel pain.
longDescription.level5: SCN9A encodes a sodium channel (Nav1.7) found in pain-sensing nerves. Without working Nav1.7, pain signals can't travel to the brain. These individuals also often can't smell, because the same channel is used in the nose.
longDescription.level6: Congenital insensitivity to pain (CIP) is extremely rare. Affected individuals suffer frequent injuries, burns, and broken bones because they can't feel pain warnings. Most also have anosmia (no sense of smell).
longDescription.level7: SCN9A loss-of-function mutations prevent action potential generation in nociceptive neurons. Interestingly, gain-of-function mutations in the same gene cause extreme pain disorders like erythromelalgia.
longDescription.level8: Nav1.7 is the threshold channel for nociceptor activation. Complete loss causes CIP; partial loss is being explored as a target for non-addictive analgesics.

funFact.level3: People with no pain sense often get lots of injuries without noticing!
funFact.level4: Pain-free people often bite their tongues, burn themselves, and break bones without realizing it. Pain actually protects us!
funFact.level5: Drug companies are trying to make painkillers that partially block Nav1.7, to reduce pain without completely eliminating the protective warnings.
funFact.level6: The opposite mutation (hyperactive Nav1.7) causes burning pain disorders. The same gene controls both extremes.
funFact.level7: SCN9A gain-of-function causes paroxysmal extreme pain disorder or erythromelalgia - showing the gene's critical role in pain signaling.
funFact.level8: Nav1.7 inhibitors are in development as non-opioid analgesics, though achieving full analgesia without side effects has been challenging.

inheritanceExplanation.level3: You need two broken copies of the gene to feel no pain.
inheritanceExplanation.level4: Pain insensitivity is recessive - carriers with one working copy are normal.
inheritanceExplanation.level5: Complete loss of pain sensation requires inheriting mutations from both parents.
inheritanceExplanation.level6: CIP follows autosomal recessive inheritance; heterozygotes have normal pain sensitivity.
inheritanceExplanation.level7: SCN9A loss-of-function shows recessive inheritance, unlike the gain-of-function mutations which are dominant.
inheritanceExplanation.level8: Recessive inheritance is consistent with haploinsufficiency not affecting nociceptor function; 50% Nav1.7 is sufficient for normal pain perception.

traits.prevalence: Extremely rare (<1 in 1,000,000)

traits.name: Myostatin and Muscle Growth

shortDescription.level3: A gene that normally limits how big muscles can grow!
shortDescription.level4: Myostatin is a natural brake on muscle growth. Rare mutations remove this brake.
shortDescription.level5: Myostatin inhibits muscle growth; loss-of-function mutations cause dramatically increased muscle mass.
shortDescription.level6: MSTN encodes myostatin, a muscle growth inhibitor. Null mutations cause 'double muscling' in cattle and extreme muscularity in humans.
shortDescription.level7: Myostatin is a TGF-β family member that inhibits myoblast proliferation; loss-of-function causes muscle hypertrophy.
shortDescription.level8: Myostatin signals through ActRIIB to activate SMAD2/3, inhibiting MyoD expression. Null mutations cause 40-100% increases in muscle mass in mammals.

longDescription.level3: Your body makes a protein called myostatin that tells your muscles when to stop growing. In rare cases, this protein doesn't work and people become extremely muscular naturally!
longDescription.level4: Myostatin is like a brake pedal for muscle growth. Animals and rare humans with broken myostatin genes develop huge muscles with little exercise. This is called 'double muscling.'
longDescription.level5: The MSTN gene makes myostatin, which limits muscle growth. 'Belgian Blue' cattle and 'Bully' whippets have myostatin mutations, making them extremely muscular. Rare humans with these mutations show similar effects.
longDescription.level6: Myostatin is a negative regulator of muscle mass. A German child with homozygous MSTN mutation was extraordinarily muscular at birth. Cattle breeds selected for 'double muscling' carry myostatin mutations.
longDescription.level7: Myostatin signals through activin type II receptors to inhibit satellite cell activation. Blockade increases both muscle fiber size (hypertrophy) and number (hyperplasia).
longDescription.level8: Myostatin inhibition therapies are being developed for muscular dystrophy and sarcopenia. Approaches include follistatin overexpression, anti-myostatin antibodies, and ActRIIB decoys.

funFact.level3: Belgian Blue cattle have so much muscle they sometimes need C-sections to give birth!
funFact.level4: A German boy with a myostatin mutation could hold 7-pound weights with arms extended at age 4!
funFact.level5: 'Bully' whippets with one myostatin mutation are actually faster than normal whippets. Two mutations make them too bulky to run well.
funFact.level6: Myostatin inhibitors are banned in sports. Some athletes have been caught using experimental myostatin-blocking drugs.
funFact.level7: Heterozygous myostatin mutations may enhance athletic performance; elite athletes show lower myostatin levels and rare variants.
funFact.level8: Myostatin polymorphisms (K153R) associate with muscle strength differences in normal populations, though effects are modest compared to null mutations.

inheritanceExplanation.level3: Even one copy of the mutation makes muscles bigger!
inheritanceExplanation.level4: One myostatin mutation increases muscles somewhat. Two mutations cause extreme muscle growth.
inheritanceExplanation.level5: Myostatin mutations show dose effects: one copy increases muscle somewhat, two copies cause dramatic muscling.
inheritanceExplanation.level6: MSTN shows codominant inheritance; heterozygotes have intermediate muscle hypertrophy compared to homozygotes.
inheritanceExplanation.level7: Haploinsufficiency causes partial muscle hypertrophy; homozygous loss causes ~40-100% muscle mass increase.
inheritanceExplanation.level8: Gene dosage effects are evident: 50% myostatin reduction (heterozygotes) increases lean mass ~20-30%, while null causes more dramatic effects.

traits.prevalence: Extremely rare in humans; common in some cattle breeds bred for it

traits.name: Celiac Disease Susceptibility

shortDescription.level3: When gluten makes your immune system attack your gut!
shortDescription.level4: Celiac disease is when eating gluten damages your intestines.
shortDescription.level5: HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 genes are necessary but not sufficient for celiac disease.
shortDescription.level6: Celiac disease requires specific HLA genotypes plus environmental trigger (gluten).
shortDescription.level7: HLA-DQ2.5/DQ8 present gluten-derived deamidated peptides to T cells, triggering autoimmune enteropathy.
shortDescription.level8: Tissue transglutaminase deamidates gliadin peptides, increasing HLA-DQ2/8 binding affinity and triggering CD4+ T cell responses.

longDescription.level3: Celiac disease happens when eating gluten (found in wheat, bread, and pasta) makes your immune system attack your own intestines. It runs in families.
longDescription.level4: People with celiac disease can't eat gluten because their immune system mistakes it for an invader and damages their intestines. Specific genes (HLA-DQ2/DQ8) make this possible.
longDescription.level5: Celiac disease requires inheriting specific HLA genes (DQ2 or DQ8) that present gluten fragments to the immune system in a way that triggers an attack. However, only ~3% of people with these genes develop celiac disease.
longDescription.level6: HLA-DQ2 (specifically DQ2.5) and HLA-DQ8 are necessary for celiac disease. The HLA molecules present deamidated gluten peptides to T cells, but additional genetic and environmental factors determine who develops disease.
longDescription.level7: ~95% of celiac patients carry HLA-DQ2.5 (DQA1*05/DQB1*02) or HLA-DQ8 (DQA1*03/DQB1*03:02). Tissue transglutaminase deamidates gluten, increasing DQ binding affinity.
longDescription.level8: Celiac pathogenesis involves TG2-mediated gliadin deamidation, HLA-DQ2/8-restricted CD4+ T cell activation, IFN-γ production, and cytotoxic CD8+ IEL expansion causing villous atrophy.

funFact.level3: Celiac disease has become much more common in the last 50 years!
funFact.level4: Celiac disease has increased 4-fold since the 1950s, and no one knows exactly why. The genes haven't changed that fast!
funFact.level5: Having the celiac risk genes without disease might actually be protective against certain infections, which could explain why the genes are common.
funFact.level6: The 'hygiene hypothesis' suggests reduced infections may allow autoimmune diseases like celiac to manifest in genetically susceptible people.
funFact.level7: Environmental factors triggering celiac in HLA-DQ2+ individuals may include early gluten introduction timing, viral infections (especially reovirus), and gut microbiome composition.
funFact.level8: Reovirus infection may trigger loss of oral tolerance to gluten in genetically susceptible individuals by promoting TH1 responses and blocking regulatory T cell induction.

inheritanceExplanation.level3: Having the genes doesn't mean you'll get celiac - other things matter too!
inheritanceExplanation.level4: You need the HLA genes AND something else (maybe a virus?) to develop celiac disease.
inheritanceExplanation.level5: Celiac has complex inheritance: HLA genes are necessary but only ~3% of carriers develop disease. Other genes and environment matter.
inheritanceExplanation.level6: HLA-DQ2/8 are necessary but not sufficient; ~40% of the population carries risk alleles but only 1% develops celiac disease.
inheritanceExplanation.level7: HLA explains ~40% of genetic risk; GWAS has identified 40+ additional non-HLA loci with small effects.
inheritanceExplanation.level8: Celiac risk is polygenic (40+ loci) with HLA as the major determinant; environmental triggers (gluten exposure, infections) modulate penetrance.

traits.prevalence: ~1% in Europeans; HLA-DQ2/8: ~40% of population

traits.name: Hereditary Hemochromatosis

shortDescription.level3: When your body absorbs too much iron!
shortDescription.level4: Hemochromatosis makes your body store too much iron, which can damage organs.
shortDescription.level5: HFE gene mutations cause excess iron absorption and accumulation.
shortDescription.level6: HFE C282Y disrupts hepcidin regulation, causing uncontrolled intestinal iron absorption.
shortDescription.level7: HFE mutations impair hepcidin signaling, leading to increased ferroportin-mediated iron export and systemic iron overload.
shortDescription.level8: HFE normally regulates hepcidin transcription via BMP/SMAD signaling; C282Y disrupts HFE-TfR2 interaction, reducing hepcidin and increasing iron absorption.

longDescription.level3: Iron is important for your blood, but too much iron is dangerous. Some people's bodies absorb too much iron from food, and it builds up in their organs.
longDescription.level4: Hereditary hemochromatosis makes your body absorb too much iron from food. Over time, iron builds up in the liver, heart, and pancreas, causing damage. It's treatable if caught early.
longDescription.level5: The HFE gene controls how much iron your body absorbs. A common mutation (C282Y) breaks this regulation, causing iron overload. About 1 in 200 people of Northern European descent are affected.
longDescription.level6: HFE mutations disrupt hepcidin production. Hepcidin normally limits iron absorption; without it, excess iron accumulates. C282Y homozygotes absorb 2-3x normal iron, but penetrance is incomplete.
longDescription.level7: HFE C282Y is the most common Mendelian disorder in Europeans. Despite high allele frequency (~6%), clinical penetrance is only 10-30% due to modifying factors (diet, blood loss, alcohol).
longDescription.level8: The C282Y mutation disrupts HFE disulfide bonding, preventing β2-microglobulin association and surface expression. This impairs TfR2-mediated iron sensing and hepcidin induction.

funFact.level3: The treatment is simply giving blood regularly to remove the extra iron!
funFact.level4: Hemochromatosis is called the 'Celtic Curse' because it's most common in Irish and Northern European people.
funFact.level5: The hemochromatosis mutation may have been selected for during times of iron-poor diets or helped women survive childbirth blood loss.
funFact.level6: The C282Y mutation arose ~60-70 generations ago and spread in Northern Europe, possibly due to heterozygote advantage during iron-scarce conditions.
funFact.level7: Phlebotomy (bloodletting) effectively treats hemochromatosis - an ironic validation of the historical practice for very different reasons.
funFact.level8: The C282Y frequency shows founder effect from a single mutation ~4000 years ago in Celtic/Viking populations, with selection possibly driven by iron deficiency protection.

variants.effect: A/A (C282Y) = iron overload risk

inheritanceExplanation.level3: You need two copies of the iron-absorbing gene to have problems.
inheritanceExplanation.level4: Hemochromatosis is recessive - you need mutations from both parents. But even then, not everyone gets sick.
inheritanceExplanation.level5: HFE hemochromatosis requires two C282Y copies, but only 10-30% of homozygotes develop clinical disease.
inheritanceExplanation.level6: Classic recessive inheritance but with incomplete penetrance; modifiers include sex (men higher risk), alcohol, diet, and other genes.
inheritanceExplanation.level7: Penetrance is ~28% in men and ~1% in women, reflecting iron loss through menstruation protecting females.
inheritanceExplanation.level8: C282Y homozygosity shows sex-dependent penetrance: elevated ferritin in ~80% but cirrhosis in only 5-10%, modified by HAMP, HJV, and TfR2 variants.

traits.prevalence: C282Y homozygotes: ~1 in 200 Europeans; clinical disease: 1 in 500-1000

shortDescription.level3: Helps decide your eye color!
shortDescription.level4: This gene helps make the color in your eyes.
shortDescription.level5: OCA2 controls how much melanin pigment is made in your eyes.
shortDescription.level6: The OCA2 gene encodes a protein involved in melanin synthesis, affecting eye and skin color.
shortDescription.level7: OCA2 encodes a melanosomal transmembrane protein essential for melanin biosynthesis.
shortDescription.level8: OCA2 encodes a 12-transmembrane domain protein localized to melanosomes, functioning in melanin synthesis via pH regulation.

genes.name: HECT And RLD Domain Containing E3 Ubiquitin Protein Ligase 2

shortDescription.level3: Turns the eye color gene on or off!
shortDescription.level4: This gene controls whether the eye color gene is active.
shortDescription.level5: HERC2 contains a switch that controls OCA2, affecting eye color.
shortDescription.level6: HERC2 contains an enhancer element that regulates OCA2 expression and eye pigmentation.
shortDescription.level7: HERC2 harbors an intronic enhancer controlling OCA2 transcription levels.
shortDescription.level8: HERC2 intron 86 contains a conserved enhancer with an OCT1 binding site that regulates OCA2 expression.

shortDescription.level3: Decides if you might have red hair and freckles!
shortDescription.level4: This gene affects hair color, skin color, and freckles.
shortDescription.level5: MC1R controls which type of melanin your body makes - the kind for dark hair or the kind for red hair.
shortDescription.level6: MC1R encodes a receptor that determines the eumelanin/pheomelanin ratio in skin and hair.
shortDescription.level7: MC1R encodes the melanocortin-1 receptor controlling melanogenesis switching between eumelanin and pheomelanin.
shortDescription.level8: MC1R encodes a Gs-coupled receptor that activates adenylyl cyclase, upregulating MITF and eumelanin synthesis pathway genes.

shortDescription.level3: Makes the melanin that colors your hair and skin!
shortDescription.level4: This gene makes an enzyme that produces melanin pigment.
shortDescription.level5: TYR encodes tyrosinase, the key enzyme for making melanin.
shortDescription.level6: TYR encodes tyrosinase, the rate-limiting enzyme in melanin biosynthesis.
shortDescription.level7: TYR encodes tyrosinase, catalyzing the initial steps of melanin synthesis from tyrosine.
shortDescription.level8: TYR encodes tyrosinase, a copper-containing enzyme catalyzing tyrosine hydroxylation and DOPA oxidation in melanogenesis.

genes.name: ATP Binding Cassette Subfamily C Member 11

shortDescription.level3: Decides if your earwax is wet or dry!
shortDescription.level4: This gene controls your earwax type.
shortDescription.level5: ABCC11 determines whether you have wet or dry earwax.
shortDescription.level6: ABCC11 encodes a transporter that affects cerumen composition and body odor.
shortDescription.level7: ABCC11 encodes an ABC transporter affecting apocrine gland secretion composition.
shortDescription.level8: ABCC11 encodes an ABC transporter that exports lipophilic compounds from apocrine glands, affecting cerumen and axillary odor.

genes.name: Olfactory Receptor Family 6 Subfamily A Member 2

shortDescription.level3: Helps you smell cilantro - and decide if it's yummy or soapy!
shortDescription.level4: This gene affects how you smell cilantro.
shortDescription.level5: OR6A2 is a smell receptor that detects compounds in cilantro.
shortDescription.level6: OR6A2 encodes an olfactory receptor sensitive to aldehyde compounds found in cilantro.
shortDescription.level7: OR6A2 encodes an olfactory receptor that binds unsaturated aldehydes in cilantro.
shortDescription.level8: OR6A2 encodes a class II olfactory receptor with high affinity for (E)-2-decenal and related aldehydes in cilantro.

shortDescription.level3: Makes the enzyme that digests milk sugar!
shortDescription.level4: This gene makes lactase, which breaks down milk sugar.
shortDescription.level5: LCT produces the enzyme that digests lactose in dairy products.
shortDescription.level6: LCT encodes lactase-phlorizin hydrolase, which cleaves lactose into glucose and galactose.
shortDescription.level7: LCT encodes lactase-phlorizin hydrolase, the brush border enzyme responsible for lactose digestion.
shortDescription.level8: LCT encodes a β-galactosidase that hydrolyzes lactose at the intestinal brush border, with expression normally declining post-weaning.

shortDescription.level3: Contains a switch that keeps the milk gene on in adults!
shortDescription.level4: This gene has a special switch that controls milk digestion in adults.
shortDescription.level5: MCM6 contains an enhancer that keeps lactase production active in adults.
shortDescription.level6: MCM6 harbors the enhancer variant that maintains LCT expression in lactase-persistent adults.
shortDescription.level7: MCM6 intron 13 contains the -13910*T enhancer variant controlling adult LCT transcription.
shortDescription.level8: MCM6 intron 13 contains a cis-regulatory element with the -13910*T variant that prevents developmental LCT downregulation.

shortDescription.level3: Decides how bitter things taste to you!
shortDescription.level4: This gene affects how strongly you taste bitter flavors.
shortDescription.level5: TAS2R38 is a bitter taste receptor that varies in sensitivity between people.
shortDescription.level6: TAS2R38 encodes a bitter taste receptor with common variants affecting sensitivity to PTC/PROP.
shortDescription.level7: TAS2R38 encodes a GPCR detecting thiourea compounds, with PAV/AVI haplotypes determining taster status.
shortDescription.level8: TAS2R38 encodes a bitter taste receptor with three functional polymorphisms (P49A, A262V, V296I) determining PTC/PROP sensitivity.

shortDescription.level3: Affects how light or dark your skin is!
shortDescription.level4: This gene plays a major role in skin color differences.
shortDescription.level5: SLC24A5 affects melanin production and is a major determinant of skin color.
shortDescription.level6: SLC24A5 encodes a melanosomal cation exchanger; the A111T variant is nearly fixed in Europeans.
shortDescription.level7: SLC24A5 encodes a K-dependent Na/Ca exchanger affecting melanosome pH and melanin synthesis.
shortDescription.level8: SLC24A5 is a melanosomal NCKX5 exchanger; rs1426654 (A111T) shows extreme population differentiation (FST >0.9).

shortDescription.level3: Another gene that affects skin color!
shortDescription.level4: This gene helps determine how much melanin your skin makes.
shortDescription.level5: SLC45A2 affects melanin transport in skin cells.
shortDescription.level6: SLC45A2 encodes a melanosomal transporter affecting melanin synthesis and pigmentation.
shortDescription.level7: SLC45A2 (MATP) is a melanosomal sucrose transporter affecting melanin synthesis.
shortDescription.level8: SLC45A2 mutations cause OCA4; the L374F variant shows positive selection in Europeans.

shortDescription.level3: Breaks down alcohol - some people's version doesn't work well!
shortDescription.level4: This gene helps your body process alcohol.
shortDescription.level5: ALDH2 breaks down a toxic byproduct of alcohol; variants cause flushing.
shortDescription.level6: ALDH2 metabolizes acetaldehyde from ethanol; the ALDH2*2 variant causes deficiency.
shortDescription.level7: ALDH2 is the mitochondrial aldehyde dehydrogenase metabolizing acetaldehyde; E504K causes dominant-negative inactivation.
shortDescription.level8: ALDH2*2 (E504K) disrupts the active site and acts as a dominant-negative in the tetrameric enzyme.

shortDescription.level3: Helps determine if your hair is straight or curly!
shortDescription.level4: This gene affects how your hair is shaped.
shortDescription.level5: TCHH encodes a protein that cross-links hair fibers, affecting texture.
shortDescription.level6: TCHH (trichohyalin) is cross-linked by transglutaminases, affecting hair fiber structure.
shortDescription.level7: TCHH encodes trichohyalin, an intermediate filament-associated protein affecting hair fiber morphology.
shortDescription.level8: TCHH provides mechanical strength to the inner root sheath; variants affect hair cross-sectional shape.

shortDescription.level3: Affects hair, teeth, and sweat glands!
shortDescription.level4: This gene affects several traits at once.
shortDescription.level5: EDAR affects hair thickness, tooth shape, and sweat glands.
shortDescription.level6: EDAR is a TNF receptor family member affecting ectodermal development.
shortDescription.level7: EDAR V370A affects NF-κB signaling in hair follicle, tooth, and eccrine gland development.
shortDescription.level8: EDAR V370A increases receptor signaling, affecting multiple ectodermal appendage phenotypes.

shortDescription.level3: Helps fight viruses - came from Neanderthals!
shortDescription.level4: This antiviral gene may have come from our Neanderthal ancestors.
shortDescription.level5: OAS1 activates antiviral defenses and shows Neanderthal-derived haplotypes.
shortDescription.level6: OAS1 synthesizes 2-5A activating RNase L; a Neanderthal haplotype shows adaptive introgression.
shortDescription.level7: OAS1 activates the 2-5A/RNase L antiviral pathway; Neanderthal haplotypes show positive selection.
shortDescription.level8: Neanderthal-derived OAS1 haplotypes show protective effects against flavivirus infection and COVID-19 severity.

shortDescription.level3: Helps your body detect germs!
shortDescription.level4: This gene helps your immune system recognize pathogens.
shortDescription.level5: TLR1 recognizes bacterial components and triggers immune responses.
shortDescription.level6: TLR1 detects triacylated lipopeptides and forms heterodimers with TLR2.
shortDescription.level7: TLR1 forms pattern recognition complexes with TLR2 for bacterial lipoprotein detection.
shortDescription.level8: TLR1 shows Neanderthal introgression in the TLR1-6-10 cluster with adaptive immune implications.

shortDescription.level3: Protects many Africans from one type of malaria!
shortDescription.level4: This gene affects a blood cell protein that malaria parasites use.
shortDescription.level5: ACKR1 encodes the Duffy antigen, required for P. vivax malaria infection.
shortDescription.level6: ACKR1 (Duffy) is a chemokine receptor; the null allele prevents P. vivax erythrocyte invasion.
shortDescription.level7: ACKR1 encodes Duffy antigen/DARC; P. vivax DBP binds DARC for merozoite invasion.
shortDescription.level8: ACKR1 -67C disrupts GATA-1 binding in the erythroid promoter, eliminating RBC Duffy expression.

shortDescription.level3: Carries oxygen in your blood - changes can cause sickle cell!
shortDescription.level4: This gene makes part of hemoglobin, which carries oxygen.
shortDescription.level5: HBB encodes beta-globin; the E6V mutation causes sickle cell disease.
shortDescription.level6: HBB encodes β-globin for adult hemoglobin; HbS (E6V) causes sickling under deoxygenation.
shortDescription.level7: HBB E6V creates HbS which polymerizes under low oxygen, causing erythrocyte sickling.
shortDescription.level8: HBB E6V replaces a surface glutamate with valine, creating a hydrophobic patch that drives HbS fiber formation.

shortDescription.level3: Controls salt and water in mucus!
shortDescription.level4: This gene makes a protein that moves salt across cell surfaces.
shortDescription.level5: CFTR is a chloride channel; mutations cause cystic fibrosis.
shortDescription.level6: CFTR is an ABC transporter functioning as a chloride channel in epithelial cells.
shortDescription.level7: CFTR conducts chloride and bicarbonate, regulating airway surface liquid volume.
shortDescription.level8: CFTR is a PKA-activated chloride channel; F508del causes misfolding and ER-associated degradation.

shortDescription.level3: Fixes broken DNA to prevent cancer!
shortDescription.level4: This gene repairs DNA damage and protects against cancer.
shortDescription.level5: BRCA1 repairs double-strand DNA breaks through homologous recombination.
shortDescription.level6: BRCA1 is a tumor suppressor essential for homologous recombination DNA repair.
shortDescription.level7: BRCA1 functions in HR repair, cell cycle checkpoints, and transcription regulation.
shortDescription.level8: BRCA1 is an E3 ubiquitin ligase and scaffolds RAD51-mediated strand invasion during HR.

shortDescription.level3: Another gene that fixes DNA to prevent cancer!
shortDescription.level4: This gene works with BRCA1 to repair DNA damage.
shortDescription.level5: BRCA2 helps RAD51 repair double-strand DNA breaks.
shortDescription.level6: BRCA2 mediates RAD51 loading onto ssDNA for homologous recombination repair.
shortDescription.level7: BRCA2 is a RAD51 mediator essential for HR-mediated DSB repair.
shortDescription.level8: BRCA2 contains BRC repeats that bind RAD51 monomers, delivering them to RPA-coated ssDNA.

shortDescription.level3: Moves fats around your body and brain!
shortDescription.level4: This gene affects how your body handles cholesterol.
shortDescription.level5: APOE transports lipids and affects Alzheimer's disease risk.
shortDescription.level6: APOE transports cholesterol in the brain; ε4 is the strongest AD genetic risk factor.
shortDescription.level7: APOE mediates lipoprotein clearance; ε4 impairs Aβ clearance and promotes aggregation.
shortDescription.level8: APOE isoforms differ at residues 112/158, affecting receptor binding and Aβ metabolism.

shortDescription.level3: A gene where repeats can cause brain disease!
shortDescription.level4: Too many repeats in this gene cause Huntington's disease.
shortDescription.level5: HTT CAG repeat expansion causes Huntington's disease.
shortDescription.level6: HTT encodes huntingtin; polyglutamine expansion causes neurodegeneration.
shortDescription.level7: HTT polyQ expansion causes toxic protein aggregation and neuronal dysfunction.
shortDescription.level8: Expanded huntingtin disrupts transcription, autophagy, vesicle trafficking, and mitochondrial function.

shortDescription.level3: Makes a protein for fast, powerful muscles!
shortDescription.level4: This gene affects whether you're built for speed or endurance.
shortDescription.level5: ACTN3 makes a protein found only in fast-twitch muscle fibers.
shortDescription.level6: ACTN3 encodes α-actinin-3, specific to fast type II muscle fibers.
shortDescription.level7: α-actinin-3 stabilizes the contractile apparatus in fast fibers; loss shifts muscle toward slow phenotype.
shortDescription.level8: ACTN3 R577X creates null allele; XX homozygotes lack α-actinin-3 and show enhanced endurance capacity.

shortDescription.level3: Breaks down caffeine from coffee!
shortDescription.level4: This gene controls how fast you process caffeine.
shortDescription.level5: CYP1A2 metabolizes ~95% of caffeine in your body.
shortDescription.level6: CYP1A2 is the primary caffeine-metabolizing enzyme in the liver.
shortDescription.level7: CYP1A2 -163C>A affects enzyme inducibility and caffeine clearance rate.
shortDescription.level8: CYP1A2*1F affects AhR-mediated transcriptional induction, modulating caffeine pharmacokinetics.

shortDescription.level3: Controls how much sleep you need!
shortDescription.level4: Rare mutations let some people thrive on less sleep.
shortDescription.level5: BHLHE41 (DEC2) regulates circadian rhythms and sleep need.
shortDescription.level6: BHLHE41 is a circadian transcriptional repressor; mutations reduce sleep requirement.
shortDescription.level7: BHLHE41 P384R reduces repression of CLOCK/BMAL1 targets, shortening sleep need.
shortDescription.level8: BHLHE41 mutations affect circadian gene expression and reduce homeostatic sleep drive.

shortDescription.level3: Helps control sleep and wakefulness!
shortDescription.level4: This gene affects how alert you feel.
shortDescription.level5: ADRB1 is involved in arousal; rare variants reduce sleep need.
shortDescription.level6: ADRB1 A187V affects noradrenergic signaling in the brainstem.
shortDescription.level7: ADRB1 variants affect pontine noradrenergic neurons controlling NREM sleep.
shortDescription.level8: ADRB1 A187V enhances receptor activity, increasing arousal and reducing sleep need.

shortDescription.level3: Runs your body's internal clock!
shortDescription.level4: This gene helps control your sleep-wake cycle.
shortDescription.level5: PER2 is a core component of the circadian clock.
shortDescription.level6: PER2 is a negative regulator in the circadian transcription-translation feedback loop.
shortDescription.level7: PER2 phosphorylation rate determines circadian period length.
shortDescription.level8: CK1-mediated PER2 phosphorylation triggers ubiquitination and degradation, setting period.

shortDescription.level3: The master switch for your body clock!
shortDescription.level4: CLOCK is essential for your circadian rhythm.
shortDescription.level5: CLOCK is a core circadian transcription factor.
shortDescription.level6: CLOCK forms heterodimers with BMAL1 to drive circadian gene expression.
shortDescription.level7: CLOCK/BMAL1 activates E-box-containing genes including PER and CRY.
shortDescription.level8: CLOCK has histone acetyltransferase activity important for circadian chromatin remodeling.

genes.name: Olfactory Receptor Family 2 Subfamily M Member 7

shortDescription.level3: Detects the smell of asparagus pee!
shortDescription.level4: This gene affects if you can smell asparagus urine.
shortDescription.level5: OR2M7 variants determine ability to detect asparagus metabolites.
shortDescription.level6: OR2M7 is an olfactory receptor detecting sulfur-containing asparagus metabolites.
shortDescription.level7: Variants near OR2M7 affect detection threshold for methanethiol and related compounds.
shortDescription.level8: OR2M7 region shows specific anosmia for asparagus-derived volatile sulfur compounds.

shortDescription.level3: Lets you see red colors!
shortDescription.level4: This gene makes the protein that detects red light.
shortDescription.level5: OPN1LW encodes the red-sensitive cone pigment for color vision.
shortDescription.level6: OPN1LW encodes the L-cone opsin; mutations cause protan color vision defects.
shortDescription.level7: OPN1LW is in a tandem array with OPN1MW prone to unequal recombination.
shortDescription.level8: OPN1LW spectral tuning is determined by residues at positions 180, 277, and 285.

shortDescription.level3: Lets you see green colors!
shortDescription.level4: This gene makes the protein that detects green light.
shortDescription.level5: OPN1MW encodes the green-sensitive cone pigment.
shortDescription.level6: OPN1MW encodes the M-cone opsin; deletions or hybrids cause deutan CVD.
shortDescription.level7: OPN1MW and OPN1LW have 98% sequence identity, promoting gene conversion.
shortDescription.level8: Unequal crossing-over between OPN1LW and OPN1MW creates hybrid genes or deletions.

shortDescription.level3: Controls pain signals to your brain!
shortDescription.level4: This gene is essential for feeling pain.
shortDescription.level5: SCN9A encodes Nav1.7, a sodium channel required for pain sensation.
shortDescription.level6: Nav1.7 sets the threshold for action potential firing in nociceptors.
shortDescription.level7: SCN9A loss-of-function causes pain insensitivity; gain-of-function causes pain disorders.
shortDescription.level8: Nav1.7 is required for nociceptor activation; it's a target for novel non-opioid analgesics.

shortDescription.level3: Tells muscles when to stop growing!
shortDescription.level4: This gene limits how big muscles can get.
shortDescription.level5: Myostatin inhibits muscle growth; loss causes extreme muscularity.
shortDescription.level6: MSTN encodes myostatin, a TGF-β family member inhibiting myogenesis.
shortDescription.level7: Myostatin signals through ActRIIB to inhibit satellite cell proliferation.
shortDescription.level8: Myostatin activates SMAD2/3, repressing MyoD and limiting muscle mass.

shortDescription.level3: Helps your immune system recognize things!
shortDescription.level4: This gene shows your immune system what's in your cells.
shortDescription.level5: HLA-DQA1 encodes part of an immune presentation molecule.
shortDescription.level6: HLA-DQA1 forms heterodimers with HLA-DQB1 for antigen presentation.
shortDescription.level7: Specific HLA-DQA1 alleles (DQA1*05) are required for celiac disease.
shortDescription.level8: DQA1*05/DQB1*02 (DQ2.5) presents deamidated gluten peptides to CD4+ T cells.

shortDescription.level3: Shows gluten to your immune cells!
shortDescription.level4: This gene can present gluten in a way that causes celiac disease.
shortDescription.level5: HLA-DQB1 alleles determine celiac disease susceptibility.
shortDescription.level6: HLA-DQB1*02 (DQ2) and DQB1*03:02 (DQ8) present gluten peptides.
shortDescription.level7: DQB1*02 encodes the beta chain of DQ2, essential for celiac pathogenesis.
shortDescription.level8: The DQ2 peptide-binding groove preferentially binds negatively charged deamidated gluten peptides.

shortDescription.level3: Controls how much iron your body absorbs!
shortDescription.level4: Mutations in this gene cause iron overload.
shortDescription.level5: HFE regulates iron absorption; C282Y mutation causes hemochromatosis.
shortDescription.level6: HFE regulates hepcidin expression to control dietary iron uptake.
shortDescription.level7: HFE interacts with TfR2 to sense iron levels and regulate hepcidin transcription.
shortDescription.level8: HFE C282Y disrupts β2-microglobulin binding, preventing surface expression and iron sensing.

shortDescription.level3: Protects your cells from becoming cancer!
shortDescription.level4: The most important tumor suppressor gene.
shortDescription.level5: TP53 detects DNA damage and stops cells from dividing or triggers cell death.
shortDescription.level6: TP53 encodes p53, a transcription factor responding to genotoxic stress.
shortDescription.level7: p53 activates cell cycle arrest, senescence, or apoptosis in response to DNA damage.
shortDescription.level8: p53 integrates stress signals via N-terminal phosphorylation, activating or repressing target genes via sequence-specific DNA binding.

shortDescription.level3: Helps fix broken DNA!
shortDescription.level4: A gene that repairs DNA damage; mutations increase cancer risk.
shortDescription.level5: BRCA1 repairs double-strand DNA breaks; mutations greatly increase breast cancer risk.
shortDescription.level6: BRCA1 is a tumor suppressor essential for homologous recombination repair.
shortDescription.level7: BRCA1 forms complexes with BARD1 for E3 ubiquitin ligase activity in DDR.
shortDescription.level8: BRCA1 recruits to DSBs via ABRAXAS, facilitating end resection and RAD51 loading for HR repair.

shortDescription.level3: Also helps fix broken DNA!
shortDescription.level4: Works with BRCA1 to repair DNA damage.
shortDescription.level5: BRCA2 directly loads RAD51 onto DNA for homologous recombination repair.
shortDescription.level6: BRCA2 mutations confer high lifetime risk of breast and ovarian cancer.
shortDescription.level7: BRCA2's BRC repeats bind RAD51 monomers to regulate filament formation.
shortDescription.level8: BRCA2 delivers RAD51 to ssDNA, displacing RPA and promoting strand invasion during HR.

shortDescription.level3: Makes fast-twitch muscles for sprinting!
shortDescription.level4: Found in fast-twitch muscle fibers used for sprinting.
shortDescription.level5: ACTN3 is expressed in type II fast muscle fibers; variants affect athletic performance.
shortDescription.level6: The R577X variant causes ACTN3 deficiency, shifting muscle toward slow-twitch characteristics.
shortDescription.level7: Almost all elite sprinters carry functional ACTN3; XX genotype is more common in endurance athletes.
shortDescription.level8: ACTN3 absence shifts muscle metabolism toward oxidative, improving endurance but reducing power output.

shortDescription.level3: May affect whether you're left or right-handed!
shortDescription.level4: One of the genes associated with handedness.
shortDescription.level5: ARHGEF6 is one of several genes linked to left-handedness in GWAS studies.
shortDescription.level6: Genetic studies implicate ARHGEF6 in brain lateralization affecting handedness.
shortDescription.level7: ARHGEF6 variants show association with left-handedness in multiple populations.
shortDescription.level8: ARHGEF6 Rho-GEF activity may affect neural development and hemispheric asymmetry.

shortDescription.level3: Helps clean up bad stuff in your body!
shortDescription.level4: A detoxification enzyme that removes harmful chemicals.
shortDescription.level5: GSTM1 conjugates glutathione to toxins for excretion; many people lack it entirely.
shortDescription.level6: GSTM1 null genotype (deletion) affects metabolism of carcinogens and drugs.
shortDescription.level7: About 50% of Europeans have GSTM1 null; this affects response to some medications.
shortDescription.level8: GSTM1 polymorphism affects Phase II metabolism of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and aflatoxin.

shortDescription.level3: Helps make energy for your cells!
shortDescription.level4: A crucial enzyme in how cells produce energy.
shortDescription.level5: PGK1 catalyzes an ATP-producing step in glycolysis.
shortDescription.level6: PGK1 is essential for glycolysis, generating ATP from ADP.
shortDescription.level7: PGK1 deficiency causes hemolytic anemia due to impaired RBC glycolysis.
shortDescription.level8: PGK1 is one of two substrate-level phosphorylation enzymes in glycolysis.

shortDescription.level3: Protects your kidneys from infections!
shortDescription.level4: The most abundant protein in healthy urine.
shortDescription.level5: Uromodulin protects against urinary tract infections and kidney stones.
shortDescription.level6: UMOD variants affect kidney function and risk of chronic kidney disease.
shortDescription.level7: UMOD is associated with eGFR in GWAS; protective against UTI and nephrolithiasis.
shortDescription.level8: Uromodulin forms aggregates trapping uropathogens and inhibiting calcium oxalate crystallization.

shortDescription.level3: Tells cells when to grow and divide!
shortDescription.level4: A master regulator of cell growth and metabolism.
shortDescription.level5: mTOR integrates nutrient and growth signals to control cell growth.
shortDescription.level6: mTOR forms two complexes (mTORC1/2) regulating protein synthesis and autophagy.
