shortDescription.level7: mTORC1 inhibition extends lifespan in model organisms from yeast to mice.
shortDescription.level8: mTOR senses amino acids via Rag GTPases and integrates with PI3K-Akt for growth control.

shortDescription.level3: Helps cells use energy!
shortDescription.level4: An enzyme in energy metabolism often mutated in some brain tumors.
shortDescription.level5: IDH1 mutations cause accumulation of a metabolite that alters cell behavior.
shortDescription.level6: Mutant IDH1 produces 2-hydroxyglutarate, an oncometabolite causing epigenetic changes.
shortDescription.level7: IDH1 R132H is common in low-grade gliomas and secondary GBM, conferring better prognosis.
shortDescription.level8: Neomorphic IDH1 mutations produce D-2HG, inhibiting α-KG-dependent dioxygenases including TET2 and JmjC demethylases.

shortDescription.level3: Tells cells to grow - too much can cause cancer!
shortDescription.level4: A powerful gene that controls cell growth and division.
shortDescription.level5: MYC is a transcription factor controlling cell proliferation; overactive in many cancers.
shortDescription.level6: MYC regulates ~15% of all genes, controlling cell cycle, metabolism, and growth.
shortDescription.level7: MYC amplification or translocation drives many cancers including Burkitt lymphoma.
shortDescription.level8: MYC forms heterodimers with MAX to bind E-boxes, globally amplifying transcription of growth genes.

shortDescription.level3: Puts marks on DNA packaging to control genes!
shortDescription.level4: Modifies how DNA is packaged to control gene activity.
shortDescription.level5: SETD2 adds methyl marks to histones that affect gene expression.
shortDescription.level6: SETD2 is the sole H3K36me3 methyltransferase, marking actively transcribed genes.
shortDescription.level7: SETD2 loss causes DNA repair defects and is common in clear cell renal carcinoma.
shortDescription.level8: SETD2 H3K36me3 recruits MSH2-MSH6 for mismatch repair and DNMT3B for intragenic DNA methylation.

shortDescription.level3: Affects how you react to certain medicines!
shortDescription.level4: Determines sensitivity to drugs used for leukemia and IBD.
shortDescription.level5: NUDT15 variants cause severe toxicity to thiopurine drugs in some people.
shortDescription.level6: Poor NUDT15 metabolizers require reduced thiopurine doses to avoid myelosuppression.
shortDescription.level7: NUDT15 deficiency is common in East Asians; CPIC guidelines recommend testing before therapy.
shortDescription.level8: NUDT15 hydrolyzes thiopurine active metabolites; deficiency leads to excessive TPMT-pathway metabolites.

shortDescription.level3: Makes insulin to control your blood sugar!
shortDescription.level4: The gene for insulin, which controls blood sugar levels.
shortDescription.level5: INS encodes insulin; variants affect diabetes risk and type 1 diabetes susceptibility.
shortDescription.level6: INS promoter variants affect expression levels and type 1 diabetes risk.
shortDescription.level7: INS VNTR affects thymic insulin expression, influencing T cell tolerance and T1D risk.
shortDescription.level8: The INS VNTR Class I allele reduces thymic insulin expression, impairing central tolerance to insulin epitopes.

shortDescription.level3: Cuts proteins on cell surfaces!
shortDescription.level4: An enzyme that releases signaling molecules from cells.
shortDescription.level5: ADAM17 cleaves TNF-alpha and EGF family ligands from the cell surface.
shortDescription.level6: ADAM17 is essential for shedding many growth factors and cytokines.
shortDescription.level7: ADAM17 processes over 80 substrates including TNF-α, L-selectin, and EGFR ligands.
shortDescription.level8: ADAM17 is regulated by phosphorylation and iRhom2 for substrate-selective shedding.

shortDescription.level3: Helps your brain store memories!
shortDescription.level4: Part of a signaling system important for learning.
shortDescription.level5: PRKAR1B regulates PKA activity, crucial for long-term memory formation.
shortDescription.level6: Mutations cause neurodegenerative disease with dementia.
shortDescription.level7: PRKAR1B mutations cause carney complex and brain iron accumulation disorders.
shortDescription.level8: PRKAR1B encodes RIβ, the predominant brain PKA regulatory subunit affecting synaptic plasticity.

shortDescription.level3: Helps cells move and grow!
shortDescription.level4: A receptor that tells cells to move and multiply.
shortDescription.level5: MET responds to HGF to promote cell growth, motility, and survival.
shortDescription.level6: MET activation drives epithelial-mesenchymal transition and cancer metastasis.
shortDescription.level7: MET amplification and mutations drive various cancers; it's a therapeutic target.
shortDescription.level8: MET activation induces invasive growth program via GAB1-mediated PI3K and ERK signaling.

shortDescription.level3: Pushes cells to divide!
shortDescription.level4: An enzyme that drives cells through the cell cycle.
shortDescription.level5: CDK4 phosphorylates Rb protein to allow cell cycle progression.
shortDescription.level6: CDK4 is often overactive in cancers; CDK4/6 inhibitors are used in breast cancer treatment.
shortDescription.level7: Palbociclib and other CDK4/6 inhibitors have transformed HR+ breast cancer treatment.
shortDescription.level8: CDK4-cyclin D phosphorylates Rb, releasing E2F to activate S-phase genes.
